title: @Meddler any changes planned for Cloud dragon?
body: Right now he feels less impactful from the rest by a large margin

replies.body: Nothing for 6.10, not sure beyond that. It is the weakest performing dragon from what we've seen, it's also the hardest to make use of though, so some of that underperformance might be learning curve. At present we're giving players a bit more time to get used to using it. We'd also like to take a look at how organized teams, whether pro or regular, benefit from it, given its more co-ordination dependent than the others.

Just a quick idea to throw out there. What if the time needed to be out of combat was lowered a tad? It feels a lot longer than other combat/out of combat effects, maybe cutting this down a little will make it feel more impactful.

Another idea I had would be for it to apply a small movement speed buff to minions when a champion is near (sorta like Baron Buff). This could help to push lanes a tiny bit more. 

(If that doesn't sound like a good idea for the cloud dragon buff, maybe it could work as a new champion passive? Every XXX seconds he/she can reassign a lane to give this movement speed buff to so they don't even really need to be in the lane. ... Just tossing it out there lol) 

I trust in the wisdom of Riot to make a good decision. (:

The out of combat time is 5s, so exactly the same as Mobi boots. Minion haste as well's an interesting suggestion if it turns out to be too weak due to lack of minion waves in the right places to take advantage of that strategic mobility.
Have you considered giving it a flat all the time bonus. For example : 5/10/15 in combat for a total of 20/40/60 while outside of combat

Would be an easy way to make it much, much more powerful certainly, suspect we'd probably then have to nerf it while out of combat. Something we want from the dragon buffs is for different games to play differently at a strategic level. Out of combat movement speed should do more for that than lower amounts of always on movement speed (or at least that's the theory, we'll see how that does or doesn't work out once enough games, including some from pro play, have occured with the new dragons).

One of the reasons Cloud feels underwhelming is that its multiplied utility decreases as champs run into the MS soft caps.  

What if part of Cloud's effect was to give players some relief from those caps?  Yes, I understand that would take some extra tech, but man it would be impactful in a singular way.
inb4 Heca. That guy breaks every systemic change to movespeed.

Ocean stacks brutally on Mundo.  It's okay for some champs to work a bit better with some dragons than others.  I don't think Hec is so top-tier right now that a few more ms is going to hurt, especially since they killed boot enchantments.
I'd be fine if the caps went away and Heca and Mundo got slightly nerfed in that regard (movespeed only), TBH. And maybe if Singed got a bit more base ms.

The only issue I have with the "dragon altering strategic play" right now is that since it's so heavily unpredictable teams can not form a composition in hopes of fully leveraging any given or set of given dragon buff(s). In general you just have to ignore that it exists while building your team and then simply cross your fingers that the stars align and you get a sequence of dragon buffs that benefit your team the most.

What I would LOVE to see is having dragons reduced to two types per game (chosen randomly), have them alternate on spawn, and some kind of system where in champion select teams would be shown which dragons would be spawning in that game (maybe even which one is first).

Yes it would remove some of the unpredictability from the game, but I'm personally not a fan of the randomness in the current system. Getting to see teams have the choice to decide between making a dragon focused comp or a team that would work well against it, etc. would be really interesting. 

This would somewhat unlock the dragon-altering-the-strategic-game that you've been looking for while still letting a bit of randomness/unpredictability exist between different games.

Imagine if teams were told "the two dragon types this game will be earth/ocean", they could opt to go for a heavy seiging comp to fully benefit from the buffs - or their opponents could pick a heavy engage team and hope to win because they know their enemies are clearly going to be repeatedly grouping around to pressure for dragon. If it were fire/air then maybe a team could opt to form more of a split push team,etc.

TL;DR: I think the new dragons are awesome conceptually but the heavy randomness, unpredictability, and not knowing about the game's state during champ select greatly limit the new system from flourishing.

Have you considered Cloud Drake granting like, 5 / 10 / 15% tenacity instead, over out of combat movement speed? Most games I've played so far, no one cares to contest Cloud Drake and considers its buff unworthy. Most cases, I'll read: "let's just get it over with so something useful can spawn next."

At least with tenacity, it becomes more appealing and a must-contest like the other drake buffs.

Also, is it possible to make contesting each drake unique? I thought it was pretty bland how each drake just auto attacks with pretty particles. Why not have Fire Drake spit out flames on the ground that causes damage over time on top of its attacks, water dragon spits out an area of frothy water that slows movement speed, cloud drake causes a knockback with each attack in an area around the target it hits, and earth drake causes 0.25 stuns with each attack or summons random walls of stone (think Anivia's Crystallization)? Or something to make contesting the drakes exciting and yet scary.

We went with out of combat movement speed because we wanted something that would influence how a team makes strategic decisions (e.g. how can we split push or rotate different now that we have a couple of stacks of this buff?). Tenacity by contrast while it can be powerful doesn't create much strategic play once acquired, more the occasional tactical 'I can take this person now that their CC's a bit weaker'.

We might go further on making the drake encounters different at some point, agree there's potential for more interesting fights there. Something we really wanted to avoid there though was chance spawning a dragon that, because of the team comp you'd picked, was much more difficult for you to do than your opponents. Things that punish melee significantly more than ranged (or vice versa, though that's fairly rare) are things we particularly want to avoid as a result.

 Also if you can tell me what is your opinion on Protobelt. Because i feel that it isnt worth to take compared to the other AP items and in every high elo stream ive seen nobody builds it either. I think that the dash is suuuuuuper short, its almost unnoticable. I wouldnt mind to take a bit of its raw stats and buff its dash

Not sure on Protobelt yet. It's certainly not the all dominating balance wrecking item some were worried it would be, we have kept its power somewhat conservative though since adding a dash to any AP champ that wants it is still potentially pretty scary. Happy letting it sit as is for now and letting people explore it on different champs/builds. If making any changes most likely would be to increase the damage fall off for multi rocket hits and shift that power elsewhere (point blanking most of the rockets may be too optimal at present).

Yeah. I see some champions with dash ability (e.g: Ahri, LeBlanc, Fizz) use Protobelt as an item providing additional nuke on their kit (similar to Deathfire Grasp), because they can pop on opponent's face and get multi rocket hit so easily.
I think a good balancing idea would be to keep the 15/30/45 ooc ms, but have it reduced to 5/10/15 instead of 0 when in combat.

Because unless you're a 5 man premade, you're going to generally play the same every game. You can't make 5 random people all play a certain way because of a dragon. And one person isn't going to be able to utilize "out of combat movement speed" on their own (at least not in a meaningful way that will win the game like the other dragons can).

The main problem with cloud drake, I think, is that its intended use (enable better out-of-combat rotations and cross-map plays) is one that doesn't come up in a large percentage of games.  Many games I see that aren't plat/diamond/challenger are pretty much 'Lane until a certain arbitrary time, then push mid and teamfight.'  There's no rotation going on, really, because rotation requires a degree of coordination not found on teams of random people.  Extra AD/AP is always meaningful.  Extra health and mana is always meaningful.  Extra objective damage is almost always meaningful.  Extra out-of-combat movespeed is useful only if you have a team that knows how to rotate and is willing to do it.  It's the only dragon that has a buff that depends on team strategy and synergy.  If everyone just wants to pile in mid and teamfight for 10 minutes (and a lot of players love to do this) then it's of minimal value.

I'd expect organized teams and high-ranking players to put this one to better use, but for the masses, it's that dragon you kill in the hopes something useful spawns.
